nodes.bodyText: @SameeraPriyathamTadikonda can you pls verify the steps noted here for DHS is what we follow in  Jenkins as well for e2e tests running against DHS.
nodes.diffHunk:

 Run the setup script first from under `marklogic-data-hub-central/ui/e2e` directory, to initialize, deploy and run flows:
 
-    ./setup.sh dhs=<true/false> mlHost=<curatoinEndpoint/localhost>
- 
+    For DHS -

nodes.bodyText: Does "curation endpoint" mean "a host with one or more app servers assigned to the Curation group in ML"? I ask because I don't believe that group is guaranteed to exist in DHS. I think what matters is that the host has all the app servers that setup.sh depends on.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4,28 +4,39 @@ This hc-qa-project is intended to run HC e2e test.
 
 Run the setup script first from under `marklogic-data-hub-central/ui/e2e` directory, to initialize, deploy and run flows:
 
-    ./setup.sh dhs=<true/false> mlHost=<curatoinEndpoint/localhost>
- 
+    For DHS -
+        * Create users as admin using the payload in cypress/fixtures/users for the tests
+        * ./setup.sh dhs=true mlHost=<curationEndpoint>
+            * example of curation endpoint is dwgz7dnkj.ec2dentifier10.a.marklogicsvc.com

nodes.bodyText:
curation endpoint is simply the Curation stack: https://docs.marklogic.com/cloudservices/aws/refs/endpoints-and-port-numbers.html and the naming(curation endpoint) is based on its usage across cloud services and our team. The portal API we use to bring up a stack, throws an output saying curationEndpoint=<....> and I understand now from @SameeraPriyathamTadikonda that its now been changed to httpsendpoint.
Its just how curation stack is referred to.

nodes.bodyText:
Instead of requiring a property to be specified, I recommend making two concrete tasks - e.g. verifyStagingCounts and verifyFinalCounts. Those are easier for a user to invoke and they have self-documenting task names.
"script" then becomes a property of your custom task class. CallResourceTask in https://github.com/marklogic-community/ml-gradle/wiki/Writing-your-own-task is an example of that.
The task with typo was still passing. Added finally and now both the tasks fail when expected. to

Quick note - fn.count on fn.collection works fine if the counts are in the thousands or less, maybe tens of thousands. But it forces every document to be read in.
The faster approach is cts.estimate(cts.collectionQuery(['...'])) . That will return a subsecond response for any number of results.
